summary: This document consists of two consecutive monthly credit card statements (January and February 2019) from Bank of America for an account ending in 160264C. The statements show a low credit limit, late fees, and purchases at various merchants including food delivery and retail. The account holder is not named in the provided text. This document consists of two consecutive Bank of America credit card statements (February 17 - March 16, 2019 and March 17 - April 16, 2019) for an account holder. It details transactions, payments, fees, and interest charges, showing the account holder made purchases in New York and the Bronx, incurred a late fee, and exceeded their credit limit. This document is a Bank of America credit card statement and associated terms amendment for an account ending in 34C. It details changes to fees effective June 15, 2019, shows a balance of $582.98 with a late fee and interest charges, and includes standard regulatory notices. The document appears to be a routine financial record with no direct mention of Epstein-related individuals, events, or locations. This document contains two Bank of America credit card account statements (June 2019 and July 2019) showing account activity, fees, interest charges, and payment information. The account appears to be in a restricted status with balances exceeding the credit limit. This document is a Bank of America credit card account summary statement for the billing period July 17 to August 16, 2019. It shows a balance of $533.31, a total credit line of $500, and indicates the account's credit line was in a restricted status and not available for use at the time of the statement.

events.title: Late Fee Charged

events.description: An online payment of $230.00 was made to the credit card account from a checking account.

events.description: Multiple purchases were made using the card at merchants including Delivery.com, Foodtown, and Collage.com.

events.description: An online payment of $300.00 was made to the credit card account from a checking account.

events.description: An online payment of $200.00 was made to the credit card account from a savings account.

events.title: Series of Purchases in NY/Bronx
events.description: Multiple purchases were made at various merchants in New York, NY and the Bronx, NY, including retail stores, cleaners, a bagel shop, and a drug store.

events.description: The payment due date of 04/13/2019 passed without the minimum payment being received, leading to a late fee.

events.description: A late fee of $25.00 was charged to the account for the missed payment.

events.description: A late fee of $38.00 was charged to the account for a payment due.

events.title: Interest Charged on Purchases

keyFacts: The credit card account (ending in 160264C) had a low total credit line of $500.00 and was frequently near or over its limit in early 2019.
The account incurred a $25.00 late fee in January 2019, which was later corrected with a credit.
Purchases on the card in February 2019 included food delivery (Delivery.com), groceries (Foodtown Bronx NY), a trip-related charge (User Trip), and an online retailer (Collage.com).
The document is a standard Bank of America credit card statement containing no direct references to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, or related legal proceedings.
The account holder's name is not visible in the provided text excerpts.
The credit card account holder made numerous purchases in New York City and the Bronx between March 5-14, 2019.
The account holder missed a payment due on April 13, 2019, resulting in a $25 late fee.
By the April 16, 2019 statement closing, the account balance of $534.91 exceeded the total credit line of $500.00.
The document shows two electronic payments totaling $500 were made to the account in late February/early March 2019.
The account terms were scheduled to change on June 15, 2019, including increases to late payment and returned payment fees.
The document is a Bank of America credit card statement and terms amendment dated March 17 - May 16, 2019.
It outlines changes to credit card fees, including a late fee of $28 (or $39 if a late fee was assessed in the prior six cycles) and a returned payment fee of $28, effective June 15, 2019.
The statement shows an account with a new balance total of $582.98, a past due amount, and a late fee of $38.00 charged on May 13-14, 2019.
The account number ends in '34C' and the statement includes standard regulatory notices (Equal Credit Opportunity Act, Fair Credit Billing Act).
There is no mention of Jeffrey Epstein, Ghislaine Maxwell, or any other individuals associated with the Epstein case within this document text.
The credit card account had a total credit line of $500.00 but carried balances exceeding that limit ($632.31 in June, $533.31 in July).
The account was in a 'restricted status' and not available for use when the statements were created.
A significant 'CHARGEOFF REAPPLY FEE' of $101.00 was applied on July 1, 2019, suggesting the account may have been previously charged off.
A 'COLLATERAL TRANSFER' credit of $99.00 occurred on July 4, 2019, indicating some form of asset-backed transaction.
Total fees charged in 2019 were $101.00 and total interest charged was $53.53 as of these statements.
The credit card account had a statement closing date of August 16, 2019, with a new balance of $533.31 against a total credit line of $500, meaning the balance exceeded the credit limit.
The account's credit line was noted as being in a 'restricted status and not available for use' when the statement was created.
The document is a standard financial record (credit card statement) with no direct mentions of individuals, events, or locations specifically tied to the Epstein case within this text chunk.
